div2.p: Africa, and the Educated and Wealthy Negroes of America.

Africa, doubtless, is the greatest land upon the face of the globe. You cannot pick up a newspaper of any note, political or religious, without seeing plans put forth by some one concerning the development of Africa. Just now, more eyes are being turned to the continent of Africa than any other part of the known world. Millions of acres of uncultivated soil, the richest upon the face of the globe, are claiming the attention of the agricultural classes of England, France, America and many other civilized portions of the world.

The great Nile, Niger, and other navigable streams flowing through the continent of Africa, mightier than the Hudson or the Mississippi, are looked at with great care by the masters of commerce, with the anticipation of making them add to the glory of the commercial world, and at the same time hoping to make them subject to the commercial centres of their governments. The gold, silver, iron, copper, and other treasures that are deposited among the mountains of Africa, awaiting the "pick and shovel" of the miners, are being talked about by the money kings of Europe and America— not only talked about, but they are laying claims to vast regions of Africa, with no other purpose than to get the rare wealth which it affords, then leave the natives in heathenism and darkness.
Through the Providence of an All-wise Creator, this continent has for centuries been protected from the wholesale slaughter of other races.

Millions of uncivilized beings, without the knowledge of race development, inhabit this greatest of great countries. Africa must be civilized. Who will do the work, and who can best do the work? are the questions that are before the thinking peoples of to-day.

The Negroes of the Southern States have been surrounded by conditions darker than any other race of mankind upon the face of the earth. The institution of slavery is ancient, but when I think of the causes that led to the building of this government—how the colonists had to fight to break the yoke of Great Britain from their necks—it looks as though it would have been impossible to ever get them to oppress or allow a class weaker than themselves to be oppressed within the bounds of this great "Home of the brave and land of the free(?)" It was not the intention of the makers of the Constitution of the United States that slavery should be carried to such a great extent, and thereby blast the name of America forever.

The hellish institution of African slavery in the Southern States of America was unparalleled in its mode of evil treatment by the master to the slave. In many parts of the world a slave has been allowed an education—at a certain age was given his freedom. But not so in the time when your and my father and mother were subject to the Southern human beast of our America. Laws were placed upon the statute books, making it a penalty for a master to teach or allow his Negroes to be taught to read and write. They were held as slaves from birth to death, regardless of what their age might be. Mothers and fathers were sold from their children, infants were taken from the cradle (?) and sold from the embrace of their mothers, to be brought up in a cold world and have their hopes blasted forever.

Something more than a quarter of a century ago,
after many debates upon the floors of the Senate and Hall of Representatives of the United States, by great statesmen, a mighty conflict for the preservation of the Union took place. This being the supreme moment of action by the lovers of liberty, they took advantage and the Negro was given his freedom. Amendments to the Constitution of the United States and conventions by the Southern States made the once Negro slave, an American citizen. Many have been the changes which have taken place in this period. Ex-slaves have been members of the Senate and Congress of the Nation, judges, legislators, district attorneys, clerks of courts, sheriffs, mayors, and in short many offices of a political and diplomatic nature have been filled by them with credit to themselves and honor to the country which made them citizens.

The Negroes of this country have proved themselves equal to every science handled by his once white master. Hebrew, Greek, Latin, German, French and many other languages are spoken by them. Mathematics, astronomy, geology and all the other sciences are mastered by the brain of the "brother in black."

The American Negro worships the same God of his former master, preaching the gospel of the blessed Christ in a purer way than any other class of people (as a whole) upon the American soil, advocating "God our father, Christ our redeemer and man our brother." Turned loose without anything to protect them, they saw the wealth of the white man, and "caught on," and to-day the Negro pays taxes upon millions of dollars worth of valuable property in the same sections where they were held as slaves. With all of the before-mentioned, and many other developments, it is strange, yet true, that the Negro will never rise to the greatness to which he aspires, the height of manhood which belongs to him, so long as he remains in this "white
man's country." Class legislation, mob violence, race discrimination, disfranchisement of citizenship, social caste, and other white American aristocratic absurdities will always keep the Negro in the background of American greatness. Therefore, if the educated and wealthy Negroes of this country would turn their attention to the development of the resources of Africa go there, cut down the forest, build up commercial and manufacturing interests with the great civilized centres of the world, organize territories, build states, shape a government, civilize the tribes, set up an army and navy—then the world will know that the Negro is a man, and can attain the same greatness as other nationalities. If the American Negroes of education and wealth would go at this work with energy and push, what will be the result? The sun-burnt sons of Africa will be seen sitting presidents over the greatest and richest country in the world; governors of states greater than New York or Pennsylvania; poets, historians, orators, dramatists, and authors of various kinds, reading the once greatness of Egypt inscribed upon the "everlasting stone," will spring up more illustrious than Whittier, Milton, Bryant, Josephus, Demosthenes, Shakespeare, Homer, or any others who have made their names illustrious in the field of letters. The "black hand" that is being trained in the machine shops of the industrial departments of the colleges of America, and then turned loose to find "iron-clad" organization of the "white brother" against him, thereby forcing him to abandon his trade as a machinist and seek other occupations for a livelihood, will take hold of the throttle, and pull the "giant horse" across the continent of our fathers, to the astonishment of the world. The medical student, who graduates in this country, and goes out to find himself hemmed off by the Southern medical examiner,
and in many instances pronounced "root doctor" by his own race; an oath in the Southern drug stores not to fill a prescription for a "nigger" doctor; these and other obstructions cause him to lay aside his profession, and go to "preaching." (?) Hence the great number of Negro preachers in this country. Why should not the medical student be included in building up this new civilization? There are plants and minerals in Africa, abounding with medical properties. The Negro doctor can have laboratories in Africa greater than any in this country. Instead of being flunkies, porters, carriage drivers, barbers, and other classes of servants, the educated will have a vast field in which to develop their skill.
After some years of toil, the Negro will see the necessity of inventions, and inventors will rise up, and the Edison and others of to-day will find their equals, or superiors.

If the American Negro would go to work—earnest work—at the development of the continent of Africa, in the twentieth century, a civilization will "loom up" on the banks of the Nile and Niger, greater than the civilization on the Hudson and Mississippi. Cities greater than New York, Chicago, Philadelphia or New Orleans. Telegraph companies mightier that the "Western Union." Railroads longer than any to be found in America. Colleges greater than Oxford, Howard or Lincoln. Lumber companies larger than any Michigan company. Clothiers greater than Wanamaker. Statesmen greater than Sumner, Garrison, Sherman, Blaine or Gladstone. Ministers surpassing Whitfield, Wesley, Spurgeon, Lindon, Beecher or Brooks. Orators will rise up to picture the greatness of the country, with tongues of fire, who will be listened to by large concourses of intelligent citizens, who will clap their hands and bless the Amer-
ican Negro pioneer. Many will say it will call for too many hardships. I answer, you cannot go through more hardships than you have gone through. Also, it can be said, of a truth, that nothing great can be obtained without hardship and toil. Therefore, if we want to live in a land where we can protect our mothers, wives, sisters and daughters from the fiendish snares that await them in this land, we must begin to develop our "fatherland." If we want to wear the full badge of citizenship, we must "go over and possess the land " that God has reserved for us for ages. Then, and not until then, will the Negro be known as a man "walking without crutches."
